name: Kamakhya
storyGoddess: Kamakhya is dedicated to Goddess Adi Shakti, representing desire, fertility, and creation. It marks the place where Sati’s yoni (womb) fell, symbolizing the creative power of the universe. The goddess here embodies the primal feminine force and is revered for blessings of fertility and spiritual awakening.
storyTemple: Situated atop Nilachal Hill, Kamakhya Temple is a major Tantric center. The temple celebrates Ambubachi Mela annually, symbolizing the menstruation of Mother Earth — a festival honoring fertility and womanhood.

name: Kalighat
storyGoddess: Kalighat is dedicated to Goddess Kali, the fierce form of Adi Shakti symbolizing destruction and renewal. It is believed that Sati’s right toe fell here, representing divine grounding and cosmic transformation.
storyTemple: Located on the banks of the Adi Ganga, Kalighat is one of India’s most revered Shakti Peethas. Devotees visit to seek liberation from ego, negativity, and life’s cycles, guided by the compassionate power of Kali.

name: Vimala
storyGoddess: Vimala Devi is the guardian deity of Puri and represents purity and divine support. It is believed Sati’s feet fell here, symbolizing stability and grounding in devotion.
storyTemple: Vimala Temple lies within the Jagannath Temple complex, emphasizing the unity of Shakti (Devi) and Vishnu (Jagannath). Pilgrims offer prayers before Jagannath darshan to honor Devi’s blessings.

name: Jwala Ji
storyGoddess: Sati’s tongue fell here, giving rise to eternal blue flames that burn naturally without fuel. Jwala Devi represents the fiery speech and cosmic truth that burns illusion.
storyTemple: The temple has nine flames symbolizing different goddesses. Devotees come to witness the eternal fire, a visible manifestation of the goddess’s power.

name: Biraja
storyGoddess: The navel of Sati fell here, signifying the center of creation and balance. Biraja Devi is worshipped as the remover of sins and grantor of liberation.
storyTemple: The ancient Biraja Temple is shaped like a naval wheel, reflecting the cosmic order. Pilgrims perform rituals for ancestral peace here.

name: Vishalakshi
storyGoddess: Sati’s earrings fell here. Vishalakshi represents broad vision and divine perception, guiding devotees to spiritual clarity.
storyTemple: Located near Manikarnika Ghat, Vishalakshi Temple forms part of Kashi’s spiritual triad with Annapurna and Vishwanath, symbolizing knowledge, nourishment, and liberation.

name: Tara Tarini
storyGoddess: Sati’s breasts fell here, symbolizing nourishment and maternal care. Tara and Tarini represent twin aspects of the Divine Mother — knowledge and protection.
storyTemple: The temple atop Kumari Hills overlooks the Rushikulya River, considered sacred. It is one of the oldest Shakti Peethas.

name: Hinglaj
storyGoddess: Sati’s head fell here, symbolizing supreme knowledge and consciousness. Hinglaj Mata is revered across borders, representing unity of devotees.
storyTemple: Situated in the Makran desert, the temple is a pilgrimage site for both Hindus and Muslims. The cave shrine radiates serenity and devotion.

name: Kamakshi
storyGoddess: Kamakshi means ‘She whose eyes awaken desire’. The goddess represents love as a path to liberation. Sati’s navel fell here.
storyTemple: Kanchipuram’s Kamakshi Temple is one of the three holy Shakti centers in South India. The deity sits in Padmasana, holding sugarcane bow and flower arrows.

name: Mahalakshmi
storyGoddess: Sati’s eyes fell here, granting divine vision. Mahalakshmi blesses devotees with wealth, clarity, and dharmic prosperity.
storyTemple: Kolhapur Mahalakshmi Temple is one of the 108 Shakti Peethas and a major pilgrimage of Goddess Lakshmi’s earthly presence.

name: Srisailam
storyGoddess: Sati’s neck fell here, and she manifested as Bhramaramba, the bee goddess. She symbolizes devotion’s buzzing vibration and protection.
storyTemple: Located beside Mallikarjuna Jyotirlinga, this temple is a unification of Shiva and Shakti energies.

name: Jayanti
storyGoddess: Sati’s left thigh fell here. Jayanti Devi blesses devotees with courage and success in righteous endeavors.
storyTemple: The temple stands amidst natural beauty, symbolizing triumph over adversity and inner fortitude.

name: Manibandh
storyGoddess: Sati’s wrists fell here, representing divine action. The goddess teaches karma yoga — action aligned with dharma.
storyTemple: Located near Pushkar Lake, this temple emphasizes right action and service.

name: Sugandha
storyGoddess: Sati’s nose fell here, symbolizing the divine fragrance of righteousness and purity of intentions.
storyTemple: The temple lies near the river Sunanda. Devotees believe prayers here remove ego and restore humility.

name: Kireet Kona
storyGoddess: Sati’s crown fell here. The goddess represents sovereignty of truth and the authority of divine law.
storyTemple: Pilgrims come to seek leadership rooted in dharma and wisdom.

name: Kalmadhav
storyGoddess: Sati’s pelvis fell here, symbolizing foundation and root energy. Aparna Devi bestows strength and balance.
storyTemple: Kalmadhav Temple near Amarkantak is revered as a source of the Narmada, signifying life force.

name: Nandikeshwari
storyGoddess: Sati’s neck fell here, symbolizing sound vibration. Nandikeshwari grants eloquence and inner truth.
storyTemple: Located in Birbhum, this temple is surrounded by tranquil nature, inspiring spiritual harmony.

name: Janasthan
storyGoddess: Sati’s right arm fell here, symbolizing divine protection. Saptashrungi Devi holds weapons to defend righteousness.
storyTemple: Perched on seven peaks, the temple represents Shakti’s vigilant strength safeguarding dharma.
